title: Will apps replace websites in the near future? - Quora

response.answer_text: No. Although this theory has been around for awhile, it is not likely it will come true. Both are completely different approaches to display contens/interactions. While Websites have benefits in their openness and easy access (you just need the browser, no need to require to "Download" it first, like an App), Apps are perfect for real, repeated interaction between a service or other users. What already happened, and will continue in the future, is the change of using both of them. Just look at websites 5 years ago and today. They have become a real commodity and many just look the same. But they are still great for gathering quick information about, e.g. a company. Apps created a whole new business, but i like to think of them as a kind of bridge technology, as they are basically closed sandboxes with mostly limited capabilities. I suppose in the future we will see something more interoperable, "Apps" that talk to each other and make use of "network effects" between different Apps you use. Google Now's intelligent newsfeed gives a hint on where the development might go.

Actually we’re moving in the complete opposite direction. Progressive web apps enable websites to be added to devices and even work offline. They get more device specific functionality and in the works they’re going to be able to do much of what apps can do now. Web apps have a huge advantage over native apps - they automatically work on every device. Yes us developers have to deal with some minor bugs in different web browsers, but even still, this is a lot easier than what traditional app developers have to do when porting their projects between different operating systems. You’re also not limited to the hardware - for example a PWA for video editing, doesn’t have to do any of the rendering on the device itself, it makes it easier to handle it all in the cloud, enabling low end hardware to compete with top of the line hardware for doing the same task. The other advantage is the file size - PWAs dont need to take up much space because the complex rendering part of the app is already stored on your device as part of it’s web browser. PWAs also have the benefit of security, they’re not native apps, they’re sandboxed like tabs in a web browser meaning they can’t affect other files on your device without your specific consent to do so. Understand though we will likely never go fully web only or fully app only. There are positives for both, and you always need a web browser on a device for PWAs to work, that means a native app. The lines are just getting blurrier and it’s great.

Mobile is the future. And the present. Remember the last time you left home and forgot your phone? I can’t really and if I would catch myself without my phone on me, I’d be terrified. Not enough? Such thing as portable phone power banks exploded on the market, making sure your phone never dies. Some say this has to do with a narcissistic addiction to social media and staying in tune with all the stuff going on around but does it? Today mobile apps start your car engine, sync with your watch, provide you with music(like your friends used to before), watch your diet, control your account and manage your expenses, take care of your commuting, and are just the extension of your eyes, ears, hands and what have you. It feels like there an app for everything. And whenever you come up with an app idea, whoops… it’s already been done. It wasn’t always like this though. Ten years ago, mobile app development was a Wild West and nobody knew what the heck they were doing back then. Mostly there were apps designed by programmers in a purely functional manner. But that had to change. The market is sensitive to new stuff especially coming from the Silicon Valley oven. So aesthetics came into play with designers turning their gaze on mobile application design.

No, I don’t, I just don’t think apps make sense for lots of things. You might go to hundreds or even thousands of different websites over the years, and I’m not about to install 1000 apps on my phone for them all. I think the web needs to be replaced, but apps aren’t going to do it. It needs to be some sort of platform where you can just render anything you like, similar to a web browser, but with all the crap taken out.

As long as there is money to make made on websites (which there is) the answer is no. Some segments may be replaced. Messaging used to have websites but lots of them are now app only. Overall for most websites the answer is no. If you don’t have your phone and you are on a public computer do you still want to be able to access the service? If you do then it make sense to still offer a web experience.

Websites will replace native applications on mobile phones. Apps require internal memory websites do not to the same extent. Mobile websites are becoming more user friendly, more practical, and doing it all at a growing rate of speed. I would expect to see more websites replacing apps in the next 5 - 10 years. They are easy to develop and not limited to specific platforms, but rather, as software improves, will become a one-site-fits-all solution.

I believe they already have. Look at Facebook, email, calendars et al. But the real question that keeps me up nights, or actually wakens me at 4:00 am too many days to count, is when will Voice take over the internet as we know it? Soon. Some of the behind the scenes efforts will be made known at Voice Summit 2018 on July 24,25, and 26th in Newark, NJ. Join us.

Nope. Desktop and Mobile users use both of this platforms. In future we will have a loot of apps and they will be another as now. When you travel with family you will use mobile app http://yunoapp.com/blog/features-to-consider-in-the-travel-app-development/ not the desktop version of services or websites.

I can see that happening, how much time do you use facebook in the browser instead of just using the app? Not very much right? That is a prime example on why I feel apps will over take websites, it is just was more convenient to do so. Please check out my apps Funny Burns and Insults - Apps on Google Play

I think the line will continue to blur until it is hard to define what an app is vs what a website is. They keep coming closer and closer together. And if you ditch the web browser frame they get ever closer in experience to the common person.
